Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: An Integrated Multiscale Modeling and Experimental Approach to High Cycle Fatigue Life Prediction

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this collaborative project is to investigate high cycle fatigue failure in representative engineering alloys (304 austenitic stainless steel, Inconel 718+ Ni-based superalloy and Ti-6Al-4V alloy) with a tightly integrated modeling/experimental approach. A computational framework will be established based on the integration of an enriched space-time finite element method and a multiscale fatigue damage model. With this approach, new knowledge will be gained through studies on key factors such as load cycles, stress history and triaxiality, nonlinear coupling among the loads, and complex geometry, which are known to critically influence the fatigue failure and generally not fully accounted for in the empirical design approaches that are being practiced today. The fundamental mechanisms revealed through the computational efforts will be verified and validated through existing experimental data as well as proposed high cycle fatigue tests featuring in-situ monitoring of fatigue crack initiation and propagation. Additionally, microstructural characterization will be performed to establish a map between the observed microstructural deformation mechanism and the proposed multiscale material model.

If successful, this project will shed new night on the fundamental mechanisms that govern the high cycle fatigue failure in many critical engineering applications. Examples include turbines used for energy and power applications, aerospace structural components, and high-performance electronics. The multiscale simulation models and experimental techniques developed from this project will also be of interest to other researchers who are studying high cycle fatigue mechanism for a broader range of materials and devices. The acquired research results on the topic of high cycle fatigue will be fully incorporated into the undergraduate/graduate curricula. With a cyber-enabled approach, the knowledge will be disseminated through a variety of channels towards a wide range of audiences, including graduates, undergraduates, K-12 and underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project involved the development of a novel multiscale simulation tool to investigate high cycle fatigue (HCF) failure and the influence of advanced mechanical surface treatments in representative engineering alloys and elastomers. While HCF dominates the application of many critical engineering components and structures, current design practices are heavily empirical in nature and often lead to designs that are either overly conservative or unsafe. The proposed approach embodies the key notion of multiple temporal scales that are associated with HCF application, and further incorporates a multiscale material model that accounts for the progressive damage evolution as a result of the cyclic loads. The experimental work at the University of Cincinnati was focused on the effects of advanced mechanical surface treatments of laser shock peening (LSP) and ultrasonic nanocrystal surface modification (UNSM) on the tensile properties and fatigue behavior of the nickel-base superalloy ATI 718 Plus at room and elevated temperatures and a low modulus beta titanium alloy, coupled with detailed characterization of microstructure, deformation and fracture modes, was studied. Remarkable improvements in the fatigue life from these surface treatments at room and elevated temperatures was discovered and mechanistic understanding for these improvements was attained. The experimental results served as input to the simulation tools developed successfully with the PIs group at the University of Texas at Dallas. Implementations on various high performance computing (HPC) have also been developed to enable practical application of HCF life predictions. A tightly integrated educational and outreach program was also established as part of the project objectives. More specifically, this project has provided training opportunities at the University of Cincinnati for 2 graduate students, one PhD and one M.S. both of whom have graduated. In addition, 4 undergraduate students from the Cincinnati State Technical and Community College worked on this project as co-ops with scholarships from the Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation Program and gained valuable experience. The research results generated from this project have been incorporated in a number of core undergraduate and graduate courses. In addition, the research results have also been disseminated through conference presentations, departmental/national/international seminars and over 15 peer-referred publications in high-quality journals.


Last Modified: 08/18/2017
Modified by: Vijay K Vasudevan
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This project involved the development of a novel multiscale simulation tool to investigate high cycle fatigue (HCF) failure and the influence of advanced mechanical surface treatments in representative engineering alloys and elastomers. While HCF dominates the application of many critical engineering components and structures, current design practices are heavily empirical in nature and often lead to designs that are either overly conservative or unsafe. The proposed approach embodies the key notion of multiple temporal scales that are associated with HCF application, and further incorporates a multiscale material model that accounts for the progressive damage evolution as a result of the cyclic loads. The experimental work at the University of Cincinnati was focused on the effects of advanced mechanical surface treatments of laser shock peening (LSP) and ultrasonic nanocrystal surface modification (UNSM) on the tensile properties and fatigue behavior of the nickel-base superalloy ATI 718 Plus at room and elevated temperatures and a low modulus beta titanium alloy, coupled with detailed characterization of microstructure, deformation and fracture modes, was studied. Remarkable improvements in the fatigue life from these surface treatments at room and elevated temperatures was discovered and mechanistic understanding for these improvements was attained. The experimental results served as input to the simulation tools developed successfully with the PIs group at the University of Texas at Dallas. Implementations on various high performance computing (HPC) have also been developed to enable practical application of HCF life predictions. The research results generated from this project have been incorporated in a number of core undergraduate and graduate courses. In addition, the research results have also been disseminated through conference presentations, departmental/national/international seminars and over 15 peer-referred publications in high-quality journals.
